INVESTMENT AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Investment Proposal  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will provide a senior loan of 
up to $20 million (denominated in dollars) to Bank Republic, Joint-
Stock Company of Georgia.  
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector (subsector): Financial (banking systems) 
Themes  (subthemes):  Economic  growth  (promoting  economic 
efficiency  and  enabling  business  environment),  private  sector 
development (private sector investment) 
Location impact: Urban (high), rural (low) 
   
Environmental and  Environment:                         Category FI 
Social Safeguards  Indigenous Peoples:             Category C 
Classification  Involuntary Resettlement:     Category C 
   
Investment Description  It is proposed that ADB provide a senior loan of up to $20 million 
(denominated in dollars) to Bank Republic, the proceeds of which 
will be onlent to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in 
Georgia.  Bank  Republic  has  identified  the  development  of  the 
SME sector in Georgia as a key objective in its business strategy, 
in addition to its being central to the recovery of the economy in 
the aftermath of the armed conflict with the Russian Federation in 
August 2008 and the global economic downturn. The proposed 
loan will be fully and unconditionally guaranteed for commercial 
risks by Société Générale, Bank Republic’s majority owner. 
   
Financial Intermediary  Bank  Republic  is  among  the  oldest  privately  owned  banks  in 
Georgia, and was founded as a joint-stock company in 1991. It is 
the third-largest bank in Georgia, with total assets of GEL756 
million ($451 million) as of 30 June 2009. The bank has a network 
of 26 branches and 19 service centers which provide a range of 
retail, corporate, and financial services products. Bank Republic is 
60% owned by Société Générale (among the leading European 
financial services companies), which acquired its shares in 2006. 
In  the  same  year,  the  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and 
Development acquired a 10% shareholding in the bank.  
   
Development Impact  ADB’s  proposed  loan  will  support  the  growth  of  the  emerging 
banking sector in Georgia and increase SME access to financing. 
This will be achieved through relatively long-term funding (a 4-
year loan) for SME lending by Bank Republic, to enable it to 
expand its loan portfolio. 
 
(i)  Impact. The transaction will (a) provide systemic support 
to the Georgian banking sector at a critical point in its 
development and help to renew confidence in the country's 
banking  system,  (b)  allow  Bank  Republic  to  increase 
financial intermediation in line with its strategic plans, and 
(c) contribute to private sector development in Georgia by

ii   
helping  to  mobilize  liquidity  and  channel  it  towards  the 
most  productive  investments  through  the  extension  of 
credit. 
 
(ii)  Outcome. With the help of debt funding from ADB, Bank 
Republic  will  renew  its  lending  activities,  which  will 
contribute to increasing confidence in the banking sector, 
and provide increased, sustainable access to finance to 
SMEs in Georgia.  
 
(iii)  Outputs.  Bank  Republic  will  use  the  proceeds  of  the 
senior loan from ADB to expand its SME loan portfolio.  
   
Proposed ADB  ADB will provide a dollar-denominated senior loan of up to $20 
Assistance  million to Bank Republic for up to 4 years, with a grace period of 1 
year, an availability period of 1 year, and semiannual repayments. 
The proposed loan will be sourced from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources  and  will  carry  an  interest  rate  based  on  the  London 
interbank  offered  rate  plus  a  margin  determined  by  ADB’s 
investment committee. The committee will also determine the up-
front and commitment fees. The proposed loan will be unsecured 
but  it  will  be  fully  and  unconditionally  guaranteed  (subject  to 
certain  political  risk  exclusions)  by  Société  Générale,  Bank 
Republic’s majority shareholder. 
   
Risks and Mitigating  Comprehensive due diligence conducted by ADB to gauge the 
Measures  viability of the proposed investment determined the risks overall to 
be  acceptable  for  a  transaction  of  this  kind.  The  main  risks 
identified were (i) political instability, both regionally and internally; 
(ii) political violence; (iii) declining macroeconomic conditions; (iv) 
weak banking and financial sector; (v) deteriorating asset quality; 
(vi) low capitalization; and (vii) increasing competition. 
 
The identified risks are mitigated by the following considerations: 
(i) the risk of payment default is unconditionally and irrevocably 
guaranteed by Société Générale, subject to certain political risk 
exclusions; (ii) the range of political risk exposure retained by ADB 
under  this  transaction  is  to  some  degree  mitigated  by  ADB's 
relationship  with  the  Government  of  Georgia;  and  (iii)  Bank 
Republic has strong shareholder support. 
   
Justification / ADB Value  Justification for the loan is based on the following considerations: 
Added   
(i)  Systemic  support  for  Georgian  banking  sector.  The 
proposed  loan  will  provide  systemic  support  to  the 
Georgian  banking  sector  at  a  critical  point  in  its 
development and help to renew confidence in the country’s 
banking  system.  Lending  activity  among  the  banks  in 
Georgia  has  all  but  stopped  as  a  consequence  of  the 
conflict and global crisis. As banks are a key source of 
small and micro loans for the private sector, in particular

iii
for individual entrepreneurs and SMEs, they are crucial to 
the recovery of the Georgian economy. 
 
(ii)  Increase  access  to  SME  financing.  The  proposed 
transaction  will  foster  Bank  Republic’s  SME  financing 
operations by providing debt funding needed for renewal of 
lending to this particular sector. This will in turn help to 
expand the SME sector itself, which is a main force behind 
economic growth in Georgia and contributes significantly to 
employment creation.   
 
(iii)  Catalyze foreign funds into Georgia. In conjunction with 
market  support  from  other  international  financial 
institutions, ADB's proposed loan will provide a signal of 
confidence in the underlying fundamentals of the Georgian 
economy and the banking sector during the current period 
of  uncertainty  and  help  to  catalyze  a  return  of  foreign 
investment into the country.   
 
(iv)  Support of foreign investment. ADB's proposed loan and 
its coverage of the political risks in the transaction will also 
provide support to Société Générale's long-term objective 
of expanding its role in the development of the Georgian 
banking sector and in expanding SME lending in particular. 
Société  Générale  perceives  ADB's  relationship  with  the 
Government of Georgia as providing it some measure of 
comfort  for  the  political  risks  associated  with  its 
participation, as a private sector entity, in the country's 
economic development. 
   
Implementation  The proposed terms of the loan documentation will require Bank 
Arrangements  Republic to submit financial statements and information on the 
sub-borrowers on a routine basis.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
dollar-denominated senior loan of up to $20 million with a tenor of up to 4 years to Bank 
Republic, Joint-Stock Company of Georgia for the purpose of onlending to small and medium-
sized enterprises (SMEs) in Georgia. The commercial risks associated with the proposed loan 
will be fully and unconditionally guaranteed by Société Générale, the majority shareholder of 
Bank  Republic. The  design  and monitoring  framework  is  in  Appendix  1  and  the  summary 
poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 2. 
 
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Economic and Sector Background 
 
1.  Economic Overview 
 
2.  The Georgian economy experienced unprecedented growth during 2003–2007 as a 
result of macroeconomic stabilization, structural reform, and economic liberalization measures.1 
Dramatic improvements in the business environment and massive inflows of foreign direct 
investment  fueled  Georgia's  economic  growth,  particularly  in  nontradable  sectors  such  as 
financial services and construction. Real gross domestic product (GDP) grew by an average of 
9.7% during this period, peaking in 2007 with growth of 12.4% (Table 1). Georgia’s economic 
performance during this time also benefited from stronger public finances as a result of tax 
reforms, anticorruption efforts, and the reduction of the shadow economy.  
 
3.  The underpinnings of economic growth and stability in Georgia, however, were shaken 
as a result of the twin crises which occurred in 2008. In August 2008, tensions with the Russian 
Federation reached a climax when armed conflict broke out between the two countries over the 
regions of Abkhazia and South Ossetia. Although brief, the economic disruption caused by this 
conflict, when combined with the onset of the global financial downturn in the autumn of 2008, 
adversely  impacted  the  Georgian  economy.  Before  the  conflict  and  exogenous  economic 
shocks, GDP growth was forecast to be 8%–9% for both 2008 and 2009. In the aftermath, 
 
overall growth was dampened by the damage to infrastructure and the disruption in several 
sectors of the economy including construction and transportation. Increased security concerns 
eroded confidence and resulted in temporary deposit withdrawals from banks, depreciation 
pressures, and a slowdown in bank lending. The global economic downturn led to a further 
slowdown in foreign direct investment and a drying up of private international borrowing, which 
continued through the first half of 2009. The situation was further aggravated by the decline in 
remittances, a slowdown in Georgia's export markets, and the curtailing of lending by Georgian 
banks. As a result, GDP growth dropped to 2.1% in 2008 and is forecast to contract by 4.0% in 
2009 before returning to growth, albeit sluggish at 2.0%, in 2010. Medium-term growth is 
expected to rise gradually to 5.0%, although projections are predicated on the size of the 
economic contraction in 2009, the timing and pace of economic recovery, and the resumption of 
private capital flows (Appendix 4 has more detailed economic analysis).  
 
 
                                                 
1  Georgia was named the number 1 reformer among 181 economies by the World Bank in its 2007 Doing Business 
survey and according to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) the country was the 
third-lowest in corruption in 2007. Continued efforts have further boosted Georgia’s ranking in the 2008 Doing 
Business survey, rising to 18th from 37th in 2006.

2

  2.  Banking Sector 
 
4.  General. With the consolidation of the Georgian banking sector over the past 15 years 
(247 banks in 1995 to 19 banks as of 31 August 2009), six commercial banks2 dominate the 
market, accounting for nearly 84% of total assets and 88% of gross loans (Figure 1). The 
banking sector is fully privatized and all leading banks have foreign capital participation. Foreign 
banks such as HSBC, Halyk, Privat, and JSC Kor Bank have also established a local presence 
in the market. See Appendix 3 for peer analysis.

2  The top six banks are the Bank of Georgia, TBC Bank, Bank Republic, Pro Credit Bank, Cartu Bank, and VTB 
Georgia.

3
 
5.  Penetration of the Georgian banking system is still fairly low compared with most Central 
and Eastern European and Commonwealth of Independent States countries, although it has 
improved over the last 4 years as the scales of operations and asset bases of the leading banks 
have grown. The potential for market growth is emphasized by the comparatively low ratios of 
gross loans to GDP (29.1%) and deposits to GDP (14.7%), recorded as of year-end 2008. 
 
6.  Crisis period. The conflict with the Russian Federation in August 2008 caused a short 
disruption in banking activity. However, the short duration of military hostilities and National 
Bank of Georgia (NBG) action were sufficient to maintain the stability of the sector, despite a run 
on deposits. Pressure was contained and confidence in the system was supported, largely as a 
result of NBG measures, which included (i) initially pegging the lari to the dollar, (ii) setting limits 
on deposit withdrawals (declaring a bank holiday), and (iii) activating an uncollateralized lari 
bank lending facility. Although the run on deposits lasted only 10 days, deposits continued to 
decline, albeit at a slower pace, throughout the fourth quarter of 2008 and into the first quarter of 
2009, as the disruption of many business operations necessitated a number of both corporate 
entities and individuals to tap their savings. 
 
7.  Aside from NBG action, international financial aid was also instrumental in maintaining 
financial stability in Georgia, particularly following the European Union–World Bank Conference 
in Brussels in October 2008 when more than $4.5 billion was pledged to aid infrastructure 
reconstruction and social assistance. The NBG's measures were subsequently suspended as 
the situation normalized. After removing the peg to the dollar, the NBG allowed the lari to 
devalue by around 10% in November 2008, and has since defended the new exchange rate. 
Pressure on the exchange rate has eased off and has been fairly comfortably managed with the 
support of a $726 million International Monetary Fund (IMF) facility. 
 
8.  Sector  performance.  Key  performance  indicators  in  the  Georgian  banking  sector 
improved significantly during 2005–2007, in line with overall economic growth in Georgia (Table 
2). Credit grew on average by 68.4% during this time, while nonbank deposits increased on 
average by 49.3%. Net income also strengthened. Such improvement continued through the 
first half of 2008, but abated following the difficulties in the second half of the year. The rate of 
growth in 2008 was substantially lower for both aggregate loans (which rose by 30.6%) and 
deposits (which rose by 11.0%), and the sector recorded an aggregate net loss. During the first 
half of 2009, the sector actually contracted as aggregated total assets declined (falling by 12.8% 
from year-end 2008) and lending activity slowed significantly (decreasing by 10.4%).

4

9.  Notwithstanding the difficulties brought about by the twin crises, the Georgian banking 
sector  has  shown  a  degree  of  resilience,  helped  by  external  financial  support  which  has 
underpinned bank capitalization and liquidity. However, asset quality across the sector has 
deteriorated quite significantly and there is continued uncertainty about the deposit base. The 
aggregate ratio of nonperforming loans (NPLs) to total loans has increased by 4.9 times from 
2.6% as of year-end 2007 to 12.8% in 2008, and further increased to 18.8% as of 30 June 2009. 
So  far,  domestic  currency  loans  have  been  disproportionately  affected,  but  stress  testing 
indicates the vulnerability of the loan portfolio to further exchange rate depreciation. Despite a 
slight increase in deposits registered in the fourth quarter of 2008, following a sharp fall in the 
third quarter, the volume of bank deposits fell again in the first quarter of 2009, according to the 
NBG, registering a year-on-year contraction of 6% and a quarter-on-quarter fall of 14%. Early 
indications, however, suggest that deposits may have stabilized during the second quarter of 
2009, despite the ongoing economic contraction. Banking sector deposits increased modestly 
during this period by 6.8% quarter-on-quarter, yet continued strengthening is unclear.  
 
10.  Faced with these circumstances, and with little prospect for additional recapitalization in 
the short term, banks have continued to build up precautionary balances. Although the banks’ 
cautious attitude to lending has had prudential benefits, giving way to increased liquidity and 
improved loan–deposit ratios, it has also placed additional strains on the economy. 
 
11.  Supervision. In March 2008, the government adopted the Global Competitiveness of 
the Financial Services Sector Act that triggered broad changes in 26 other laws and aimed to 
enhance the stability and global competitiveness of the Georgian financial sector. Most notably, 
under this act, the Financial Services Agency was established as an autonomous agency 
tasked  with  the  regulatory  and  supervisory  control  of  the  banking  sector.  Although  newly 
created, it is intended that the Financial Services Agency will be merged back into the NBG to

5
consolidate supervision of the entire financial sector under one entity (draft legislation is being 
considered by the parliament). The strengthening of regulatory and supervisory control under 
the NBG was undertaken as a means to address certain vulnerabilities in the banking sector 
brought about by the twin crises to potential exchange rate shocks, declining real estates prices, 
and the possibility of a longer and deeper recession. The Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
through its Central and West Asia Department, is providing key technical assistance to the 
Financial Services Agency and NBG, as well as programmatic backup support to assist in the 
efforts of banking sector restructuring. 
 
3.  Small and Medium-Sized Enterprise Sector: Binding Constraints on Small 
and Medium-Sized Enterprise Development 
 
12.  In most developing countries, SMEs are the main source of employment and economic 
growth, acting as an important engine of growth and a key contributor to poverty reduction by 
creating employment, increasing individual incomes, and generating tax revenues. The situation 
in  Georgia,  however,  is  notably  different.  Although  SMEs  are  the  most  common  type  of 
enterprise,3  large  privatized  enterprises  dominate  output  and  employment.  The 
underdevelopment of the SME sector is apparent in statistics from Georgia’s statistical bureau, 
which reveal that, as of the first half of 2009, small enterprises (broadly defined as having an 
average of up to 20 employees and turnover which does not exceed GEL500,000 per annum) 
employed only 13% of workers and medium-sized enterprises (defined as having an average of 
up to 100 employees and turnover which does not exceed GEL1,500,000 per annum) employed 
only 14% of workers, while large enterprises (defined as having an average of more than 100 
employees and turnover which exceeds GEL1,500,000 per annum) employed over 72% (Table 
3).4 This disparity is echoed in the respective contributions of large versus small and medium-
sized businesses to the economy; in the first half of 2009, large businesses contributed almost 
90% of output, while SMEs made up approximately 10% (Table 4).5

13.  The SME sector in Georgia remains highly constrained6 despite recent improvement in 
the  enabling  environment  as  a  result  of  efforts  undertaken  by  the  International  Finance 
Corporation (IFC) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD). In 
2006, the IFC implemented the Georgia Business Enabling Environment Project, which aimed 
to improve the business enabling environment in Georgia by reducing administrative barriers to 
running and operating small businesses. The project focused on streamlining the process and 
introducing  elements  of  regulatory  impact  assessment.  In  the  same  year,  the  IFC  also 
implemented  the  Georgia  Corporate  Governance  Project,  which  worked  to  improve  the 
corporate governance practices of Georgian joint-stock companies and banks, thereby helping 
them to operate more effectively and allowing them easier access to capital. These programs, 
coupled with the EBRD's efforts to stimulate economic growth through support for microfinance 
and SME development through its Early Transition Countries Initiative and other Government of 
Georgia initiatives, have substantially reduced the administrative burden for enterprises and 
limited the amount of time spent dealing with government bureaucracy.7 Despite this, SME 
development has been hampered by financing difficulties.  
 
14.  In most of ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs), SMEs have difficulty gaining 
access to financial services and securing financing. Although bank loans are the dominant form 
of external financing, few SMEs in the region have access to bank lending (and mostly only for 
working capital). Lack of access to bank lending is considered in most DMCs as the main 
financing difficulty and a stumbling block to the sustained growth of SMEs. As seen in Figure 2, 
the situation in Georgia is no different.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                 
6  Georgian  Daily.  Available:  http://georgiandaily.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4122& 
Itemid=73. 
7 This is evidenced by Georgia's top regional ranking among Eastern European and Central Asian countries in terms 
of the ease in doing business in the World Bank's Doing Business 2009 report and the country's number 6 global 
ranking in the World Economic Forum's 2008–09 Global Competitiveness Report in terms of the ease in complying 
with administrative requirements.

7

15.  Growth in the SME sector has been severely curtailed by these financing constraints, 
which have been further exacerbated by the events in the latter part of 2008. As Table 5 shows, 
only 17% of bank lending in 2007 went to SMEs, and by September 2008 this figure had 
increased only slightly, to 21%.8 The problem derives in part from constraints on the SMEs 
themselves,  such  as  their  lack  of  collateral,  proper  bookkeeping,  and  financial  reporting. 
Another problem is the high demand for bank credit, which far outstrips the supply from banks, 
many of which have traditionally shown a risk-averse bias to SME lending. The World Bank 
notes that access to banks is a problem for SMEs and larger companies alike; of the 12 regions 
in Georgia, half have fewer than one bank branch for every 100,000 citizens.9 Georgian banks 
have started to look increasingly at the SME sector as a promising business opportunity—
particularly in the aftermath of the conflict and global crisis—given the relative resilience of 
SMEs (based on borrower performance); this is a strategic move that is well aligned with the 
economic needs of the country, as well as with the main drivers of economic growth (agriculture, 
machinery, etc.), which are often led by SMEs.

B.  Investment Identification and Selection 
 
16.  After Georgia joined ADB as a member in February 2007, the Government of Georgia 
arranged  introductory  meetings  between  the  Private  Sector  Capital  Markets  and  Financial 
Sectors  Division  (PSCM)  of  the  Private  Sector  Operations  Department  and  top  Georgian 
commercial  banks,  following  initial  meetings  held  with  the  ADB  Central  and  West  Asia 
Department. Based on those meetings, PSCM selected four banks from among the top seven 
for consideration based on their financial condition, business focus, and expressed need for 
funding—Bank of Georgia, People’s Bank of Georgia, TBC, and Bank Republic.  
 
17.  In the aftermath of the Russian conflict and the global economic downturn, lending 
activity in the Georgian banking sector has been severely curtailed as funding sources have 
dwindled. In view of the need for lending activities to resume in order to assist in the recovery of 
the real economy, PSCM has considered possible interventions. Two such interventions are 
being investigated—a new facility to Bank Republic and another loan to Bank of Georgia, given 
their presence in the market, extensive distribution networks, and established track record with 
commercial and SME lending.  
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
1.  Consistency  with  ADB's  Long-Term  Strategic  Framework  2008–2020 
(Strategy 2020) 
 
18.  Development of the financial sector is essential to ensuring sustainable private-sector-
led economic growth. Moreover, without access to formal financial services and sustainable 
social insurance (including pensions), the poor will be excluded from the growth process and its 
benefits. Under Strategy 202010, ADB seeks to strengthen its support to the financial sector at 
the regional and national levels by helping to develop financial infrastructure, institutions, and 
products  and  services.  To  promote  inclusive  growth,  it  will  seek  to  create  an  enabling 
environment for microfinance, rural finance institutions, and SMEs, and will explore the use of 
technologies to expand the reach of the formal financial system to rural areas. Through such 
initiatives,  ADB  will  continue  to  assist  in  channeling  the  region's  savings  into  the  most 
productive investments—in particular, development of the capital markets—as well as continue 
to build the capacity of financial institutions by introducing international best practices. The 
proposed loan will provide systemic support for the Georgian banking sector by contributing to 
the renewal of lending activities, notably to SMEs, which is an essential component of the 
country's economic recovery and is directly in line with Strategy 2020.  
 
                                                 
10 ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila.

9
  2.  Consistency with Country Strategy 
 
19.  Although ADB does not yet have a country partnership strategy for Georgia, it has an 
interim operational strategy,11 under which it suggests lending to, or making equity investments 
in,  private  banks,  or  making  equity  investments  in  leasing  companies  and  other  nonbank 
financial institutions or providing credit lines to them. The proposed intervention is in keeping 
with this strategy, as the loan to Bank Republic will support private sector development by 
increasing access to financing for SMEs. The proposed intervention also ties in to the recently 
approved Georgia Growth Recovery Support Program,12 which outlines current difficulties in the 
Georgian banking sector and their impact on the broader economy. Again, the proposed loan 
seeks  to  provide  systemic  support  to  the  Georgian  banking  sector  during  this  challenging 
period, not only by providing financing but also by building confidence in the broader financial 
sector.  
 
  3.  Consistency with Sector Strategy 
 
20.  Supporting financial sector development is a key focus of development assistance for 
ADB, in line with the tenets detailed in ADB’s Private Sector Development Strategy13 and 
Enhanced Poverty Reduction Strategy,14 which note improved economic growth, stimulated by 
private sector investment, as a key contributing factor in reducing poverty. ADB’s private sector 
development strategy refers specifically to ADB's role in strengthening the financial sector in 
DMCs. The strategy notes the critical importance of well-functioning financial systems for the 
development of the private sector, which in turn underpins sustainable economic growth. Many 
DMCs need to strengthen their financial institutions and create diversified financial markets that 
can finance private-sector-led growth. ADB has supported financial sector reform programs 
through public sector operations and/or direct investments in financial intermediaries in several 
DMCs through its Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD). The proposed ADB loan is 
consistent with the overall sector strategy in that it will assist in the development of the Georgian 
banking sector and increase access to financing for SMEs, thereby making private sector 
development more sustainable and ADB’s mission of poverty reduction more achievable. The 
proposed loan is also aligned with ADB’s poverty reduction strategy, which states that ADB 
seeks to promote “sound and efficient banking systems and capital markets,” since these are 
seen as “indispensable for macroeconomic stability, mobilizing savings, and ensuring availability 
of long-term financing, an essential requirement for pro-poor growth.” 
 
D.  Development Impact 
 
  1.  Impact 
 
21.  The development impacts of the proposed transaction will include the following: 
 
(i)  Support for Georgian banking sector. The proposed intervention will provide 
systemic  support  to  the  Georgian  banking  sector  at  a  critical  point  in  its 
development and help to renew confidence in the country’s banking system. 
Lending  activity  among  the  banks  in  Georgia  has  all  but  stopped  as  a 
consequence of the conflict and global crisis. As banks are a key source of small

(ii)  Small and medium-sized enterprise development. SMEs play a significant

the extension of credit. 
 
2.  Outcome and Output 
 
    a.  Outcome 
 
22.  ADB’s debt funding will result in Bank Republic being able to renew its lending activities, 
which will contribute to increasing confidence in the banking sector, and provide increased, 
sustainable  access  to  finance  to  SMEs  in  Georgia  in  line  with  Bank  Republic's  strategic 
business objectives. Indicators of this include the following: (i) business performance of the 
project itself (commercial viability with example measures such as profitability, return on equity, 
net interest margin, and asset growth), and (ii) economic sustainability (provision of financial 
services to viable private enterprises and allocation of resources with example measures such 
as increasing lending to SMEs, asset quality, and disbursements in rural areas). 
 
    b.  Output 
 
23.  ADB will provide a senior loan to Bank Republic, which will effectively use the proceeds 
to expand its SME loan portfolio. 
 
III.  FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 
 
24.  Bank Republic is a closed joint-stock company, which was established in 1991 and 
incorporated in Georgia in 1992. The bank's primary business consists of commercial activities, 
originating loans and guarantees, attracting customer deposits, and trading activities, which are 
provided by the bank through its distribution network of 26 branches and 19 service centers 
throughout the country. As of 30 June 2009, Bank Republic was the third-largest bank in 
Georgia  in  terms  of  assets,  with  GEL756.0  million  in  total  assets  and  a  loan  portfolio  of 
GEL557.6 million. Bank Republic’s primary focus until 2005 was corporate banking, particularly 
serving Georgia’s larger corporations. However, since its acquisition by Société Générale in 
2006, the bank has sought to position itself better in the market and make the transition to 
universal banking, offering retail banking services and expanding its corporate banking activities 
to include SMEs. Bank Republic seeks to build on its presence in the Georgian banking sector 
and gain market share in retail and SME banking by leveraging its association with Société 
Générale and adopting international best practices in its operations.

11
A.  Ownership 
 
25.  In October 2006, Société Générale acquired a 60% stake in Bank Republic. Société 
Générale is one of the largest financial services groups in Europe, employing 163,000 people 
worldwide in three key businesses: (i) retail banking and financial services, (ii) global investment 
management and services, and (iii) corporate and investment banking. Société Générale is 
rated Aa2 by Moody’s, A+ by Standard & Poor’s, and A+ by Fitch Ratings. 
 
26.  Concurrently, the EBRD also purchased 10% of the bank. Bank Republic's third key 
shareholder is Lasha Papashvili, the former chief executive officer of the bank who is now chair 
of its supervisory council and is also involved with a leading real estate development company 
in Georgia (Redix). Table 6 lists Bank Republic’s shareholders.

B.  Business Overview  
 
1.  Business Operations 
 
27.  Bank  Republic  offers  a  full  suite  of  corporate  and  retail  loan  products.  Corporate 
products include (i) unsecured loans, (ii) single loans, (iii) formal and revolving credit lines, (iv) 
overdrafts, (v) guarantees, and (vi) letters of credit. Each credit product is generally structured 
as short term (up to 12 months), medium term (1–5 years), or long term (more than 5 years), 
depending on purpose (i.e., working capital financing versus property development). The bank 
also offers a range of retail loan products in four general categories: (i) personal loans (for 
personal needs including consumer lending through partner merchants), (ii) auto loans, (iii) 
mortgage loans, and (iv) micro loans.  
 
  2.  Credit Ratings 
 
28.  Bank Republic is currently unrated. The bank intended to approach Moody’s for an initial 
credit rating before year-end 2008; however, given the change in operating environment, it 
postponed this until a later time. 
 
IV.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The ADB Assistance and Transaction Structure 
 
29.  ADB’s loan. ADB is contemplating extending a senior loan of up to $20 million to Bank 
Republic, with a tenor of up to 4 years, for the purpose of onlending to SMEs in Georgia. The 
loan will have a grace period of 1 year and an availability period of 1 year and will be repaid 
semiannually. The proposed loan, without government guarantee, will be sourced from ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources and will carry an interest rate based on the London interbank offered

12   
rate plus a margin determined by ADB’s investment committee. The committee will also determine 
the up-front and commitment fees. The proposed loan will be unsecured. 
 
30.  The  loan  will  be  documented  in  a  loan  agreement,  which  will  contain  terms  and 
conditions  standard  for  private  sector  loans  without  government  guarantees,  as  well  as 
covenants relating to ADB policies.15 The proposed loan will be subject to conditions precedent 
to the disbursement, including all necessary government, creditor, and shareholder approvals 
and consents, and all contractual and financial arrangements satisfactory to ADB. The loan 
agreement will include appropriate (i) representations and warranties; (ii) covenants, including 
affirmative, negative, financial, and information covenants; and (iii) events of default. 
 
31.  Société Générale guarantee. The commercial risks associated with the proposed loan 
will be fully and unconditionally guaranteed by Société Générale, the majority shareholder of 
Bank Republic. Société Générale is currently rated Aa2 by Moody’s, A+ by Standard & Poor’s, 
and A+ by Fitch Ratings. 
 
B.  Justification for ADB Assistance 
 
32.  Justification for the proposed ADB loan is based on the following considerations: 
 
(i)  Systemic  support  for  Georgian  banking  sector.  The  proposed  loan  will 
provide systemic support to the Georgian banking sector at a critical point in its 
development and help to renew confidence in the country’s banking system. 
Lending  activity  among  the  banks  in  Georgia  has  all  but  stopped  as  a 
consequence  of  the  conflict  and  global  crisis,  as  well  as  their  interest  in 
maintaining additional liquidity. As banks are a key source of small and micro 
loans for the private sector, in particular for individual entrepreneurs and SMEs, 
they are crucial to the recovery of the Georgian economy.  
 
(ii)  Increase  access  to  small  and  medium-sized  enterprise  financing.  The 
proposed transaction will foster Bank Republic’s SME financing operations by 
providing debt funding needed for renewal of lending to this particular sector. 
This will in turn help to expand the SME sector itself, which is a main force 
behind economic growth in Georgia and contributes significantly to employment 
creation.   
 
(iii)  Catalyze foreign funds into Georgia. In conjunction with market support from 
other international financial institutions, ADB's proposed loan will provide a signal 
of confidence in the underlying fundamentals of the Georgian economy and the 
banking sector during the current period of uncertainty and help to catalyze a 
return of foreign investment into the country.  
 
(iv)  Support of foreign investment. ADB's proposed loan and its coverage of the 
political risks in the transaction will also provide support to Société Générale's 
long-term objective of expanding its role in the development of the Georgian 
banking sector and in expanding SME lending in particular. Société Générale 
perceives ADB's relationship with the Government of Georgia as providing it 
some  measure  of  comfort  for  the  political  risks  associated  with  Société

V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Environmental and Social Safeguards 
 
33.  The proposed loan is classified as category FI under ADB's Environment Policy (2002) 
and as category C under both ADB's Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995) and Policy on 
Indigenous Peoples (1998). Bank Republic has already adopted an environmental and social 
management system in accordance with EBRD guidelines. ADB will review such environmental 
and social management system to ensure that it is compliant with ADB's Environment Policy 
(2002) and the guidelines in Appendix 5. If Bank Republic is not in compliance, it will be 
required to make the necessary changes.  
 
B.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
34.  Monitoring. The proposed terms of the loan agreement will require Bank Republic to 
provide the following information: (i) unaudited quarterly financial statements; (ii) audited annual 
financial statements; (iii) quarterly compliance certificates for agreed-upon financial covenants; 
and (iv) quarterly reports on the sub-borrowers. 
 
C.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
35.  Bank Republic was advised of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) 
and policy relating to the Combating of Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism 
(2003). Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and transparency, 
ADB will require Bank Republic to institute, maintain, and comply with internal procedures and 
controls following international best practice standards for the purpose of preventing corruption 
or money laundering activities or the financing of terrorism and covenant with ADB to refrain 
from engaging in such activities. The documentation between ADB and Bank Republic will 
further allow ADB to investigate any violation or potential violation of these undertakings.  
 
D.  Investment Limitations 
 
36.  The proposed transaction, once approved and signed, will increase ADB's projected 
nonsovereign exposure for 2009 to $4.39 billion based on the 30 September 2009 outstanding 
amount and the projected disbursements until 31 December 2009. Exposure to Georgia will 
increase to $36.67 million or 0.84% of total projected nonsovereign operations portfolio, while 
the exposure to the capital market subsector will increase to $57.74 million or 1.32% of total 
projected nonsovereign operations portfolio. The proposed financing is within ADB’s country, 
industry, single, and group exposure limits for nonsovereign transactions. ADB will ensure that 
nonsovereign exposure will be kept within the nonsovereign exposure limit. 
 
E.  Assurances 
 
37.  No-objection  letter.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian 
Development Bank (the Charter)16, the government will be asked to confirm that it has no 
                                                 
16 ADB. 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila.

14   
objection to the proposed ADB loan to Bank Republic. No funding under the loan will be made 
available until ADB receives such confirmation. 
 
38.  Documentation. ADB will enter into suitable loan agreements and other required legal 
documents  once  the  proposed  loan  is  approved  by  the  ADB  Board  of  Directors.  These 
agreements will be on terms and conditions satisfactory to ADB. 
 
 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
39.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve a loan of up to 
$20,000,000 to Bank Republic, Joint-Stock Company from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, 
with interest to be determined based on the procedures applicable to ADB’s nonsovereign 
operations, a tenor of up to 4 years, including a grace period of 1 year and an availability period 
of 1 year, and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in this report and as may be reported to the Board.

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A. Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
1.  The project supports the development goals of both the Government of Georgia and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
in the area of poverty reduction. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
1. Key Issues  
 
Georgia's Economic Development and Poverty Reduction Program (2003–2015)a set forth the country's first long-term 
development strategy. Although the program provided a framework for poverty reduction, it lacked clear prioritization and 
implementation was hampered by limited government resources. Following the presidential election in 2008, the government 
issued a 5-year program of key priorities for 2008–2012—United Georgia Without Poverty—which identified a number of 
political, economic, and social objectives including (i) social programs (spending one-third of the state budget on social 
programs during 2008–2012), (ii) generating employment (creating 200,000 new jobs during 2008–2012), and (iii) reducing 
poverty (halving the number of social program beneficiaries during 2008–2012, increasing the minimum monthly pension to 
$100 during 2008–2012, and providing access to state-funded health insurance for 1.2 million people, including socially 
vulnerable, teachers, military and law enforcement personnel, and employees of state agencies). The government has set a 
goal of reducing the poverty rate to 15% by 2015. 
 
Georgia has implemented far-reaching and strategic reforms during 2003–2008 with impressive results. The key outcomes 
(prior to the onset of the conflict with the Russian Federation and the global economic crisis) were as follows: (i) increased 
foreign direct investment from 8.4% of gross domestic product (GDP) in 2005 to 16% in 2007; (ii) higher tax revenue 
collection from 14.1% of GDP in 2003 to 25.8% in 2007; (iii) increased social spending by more than 5%; (iv) increased 
electricity generation and transmission from a net deficit to a net exporter; and (v) establishment of a social assistance 
program covering 148,000 households with over 600,000 beneficiaries. As a result of such efforts, the official poverty rate in 
Georgia declined from 24.1% in 2005 to 23.3% in 2006 and to 21.3% in 2007; however, World Bank figures indicate a poverty 
rate of 23.6% in 2007. Despite the progress in reducing poverty during this period, it is expected that the poverty rate will 
increase in the interim period as a result of the two crises, which have resulted in the internal displacement of 130,000 people. 
In addition, over 150,000 people have been adversely affected by difficulties related to the lack of irrigation water following the 
Russian conflict.  
 
2.  Design Features 
 
Pro-poor. Through its support for financial sector and SME development, the project will support the goal of reducing poverty 
indirectly by contributing to economic growth and directly by helping to improve access to finance, which will create 
employment opportunities, provide more investment in human capital, and smooth consumption. 
 
II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
Key Issues. ADB's interim operational report on Georgia (2008–2009)b indicates that "relatively high rates of urban 
unemployment and of rural underemployment contribute to the persistence of poverty. Net job creation rates have been found 
to be highest in small private firms, as the large privatized enterprises are downsizing and shedding labor. However, 
privatized  large enterprises  still dominate  output  and employment. Greater focus is needed  on  creating an  enabling 
environment for the development of small firms to boost net new job creation. This calls for addressing the constraints that 
such enterprises face, such as the fact that small and medium-sized enterprises face bigger hurdles in accessing finance than 
larger firms. In addition to strengthening the institutional environment, the access of such enterprises to capital also can be 
improved by (i) diversifying financial services offered, (ii) broadening the types of collateral that can be accepted by banks, (iii) 
reducing  costs  associated  with  evaluation  of  credit  information,  and  (iv)  establishing  effective  systems  for  enforcing 
repayment."

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Recent Developments 
 
1.  Gross Domestic Product Growth 
 
1.  The economic downturn in Georgia turned out to be deeper than originally expected. 
While GDP growth in 2008 was a modest 2.1%, the consequences of the conflict with the 
Russian Federation and the global economic crisis continued through the first half of 2009. Real 
gross domestic product (GDP) data indicates that the Georgian economy contracted by 5.9% 
(year-on-year) during the first quarter of 2009 and by a further 10.7% (year-on-year) in the 
second quarter due to the ongoing decline in exports and remittances, and the contraction in 
bank lending by 10.0% since the end of 2008. While the contraction affected most sectors of the 
economy, retail trade, manufacturing, and construction contributed most to the decline, leading 
to significantly reduced employment and incomes. 1 
 
2.  Inflation 
 
2.  Against  the  background  of  a  broad  decline  in  economic  activity  and  falling  global 
commodity prices, inflationary pressures have dissipated. Inflation was 5.5% (year-on-year) for 
2008, as compared with 10.9% in 2007 (year-on-year), and 12-month inflation was only 2.3% as 
of 30 June 2009 (Table A4.1).

3.  Foreign Exchange 
 
3.  The foreign exchange market has stabilized since mid-February 2009, reflecting an 
easing of balance of payment pressures. The external current account deficit has narrowed 
faster than expected, led by declining imports. Capital inflows have also fallen short of earlier 
projections. Foreign direct investment, the main driver of economic activity in Georgia for the 
past several years, fell by approximately 70.0% in the first half of 2009 relative to the same 
                                                 
1  Excerpts taken from International Monetary Fund. 2009. Georgia: Third Review Under the Stand-by Arrangement 
and  Requests  for  Augmentation,  Extension  of  Arrangement,  Rephasing  of  Purchases,  and  Modification  of 
Performance Criteria. IMF Country Report No. 09/267. Washington, DC (August).

Appendix 3  21
    
period in 2008, while there was a net outflow in nonforeign direct investment private capital 
despite  large  injections  from  international  financial  institutions  to  commercial  banks.  The 
stabilization of the foreign exchange market, which coincided with the return to auctions instead 
of fixing sessions, allowed the National Bank of Georgia (NBG) to acquire foreign exchange 
from the market in March–April 2009 and to limit its foreign exchange sales in May–June 2009 
to $34 million as compared with $130 million in January–February 2009. 
 
4.  Monetary Policy 
 
4.  Monetary conditions remain very tight, notwithstanding policy loosening, with monetary 
and credit aggregates contracting through the first half of 2009 and real deposit interest rates 
rising to 8.5%. Deposit rates have increased since the outset of the crisis as banks compete for 
a shrinking deposit base. Unlike in the immediate aftermath of the conflict, the contraction of 
monetary aggregates appears to reflect mostly a drawdown of financial savings by households 
and enterprises rather than a loss of confidence. Despite stabilization in deposits and deposit 
dollarization since mid-May, banks have continued to curtail credit to preserve adequate liquidity 
buffers in the face of ongoing uncertainty and heightened credit risk. With increased credit risk, 
intermediation margins widened steadily through February 2009, but have since come down. 
NBG's refinancing rate has been lowered repeatedly, but with limited eligible collateral available 
for accessing this window, this has only led to a widening gap between market rates and the 
policy rate. 
 
5.  Fiscal Policy 
 
5.  Due to cuts in defense spending, public expenditures were 11.0% lower during the first 
half of 2009 as compared with the same period in 2008. Despite the strict control of public 
expenditures, spending reductions in the first half of 2009 were outpaced by the decline in tax 
revenues by a substantial margin. Tax revenues declined by 17.0% in the first 6 months of 
2009, in part due to the reduction of personal income tax rates from 25.0% to 20.0%, as well as 
the reductions of taxes on interest and dividend income paid to nonresidents. 
 
  6.  Financial Sector 
 
6.  The financial sector has been resilient thus far, helped by external financial support; 
however, it remains susceptible to further deterioration in asset quality, as well as continued 
uncertainty about the deposit base. The share of nonperforming loans in total loans has risen by 
15  percentage  points  since  June  2008.  So  far,  domestic  currency  loans  have  been 
disproportionately affected, but stress testing indicates the vulnerability of the loan portfolio to 
further exchange rate depreciation. Faced with deposit outflows and little prospect for additional 
recapitalization in the short term, banks have continued to build up precautionary balances. 
Although the banks’ cautious attitude to lending has prudential benefits, given very high loan–
deposit ratios, it is placing additional strains on the economy. 
 
B.  Macroeconomic Outlook and Risks 
   
  1.  Gross Domestic Product Growth and Inflation 
 
7.  Based on a moderate recovery of activity, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) expects 
real GDP growth in Georgia to rebound to 2.0% in 2010. Over the medium term, real GDP 
growth is projected to rise gradually to 5.0%, capitalizing on a recovery of world growth, given 
the country's geographical location as a natural transit point of world trade in goods and energy,

22  Appendix 3 
very favorable business environment, flexible economic institutions, and demonstrated capacity 
for timely policy action.  
 
8.  These projections are, however, predicated on the size of the economic contraction in 
2009, the timing and pace of economic recovery, and the resumption of private capital flows. 
Further  declines  in  private  capital  inflows,  exports,  and  remittances,  as  well  as  delays  or 
shortfalls in official assistance, or prolonged domestic and regional political tensions could result 
in a deeper contraction in 2009 than currently forecast. 
 
9.  Inflation is expected to edge up as growth resumes, although still remain below the pre-
crises level at 5.0% in the medium term. 
 
  2.  Foreign Exchange 
 
10.  While foreign exchange pressures have eased recently, they could reemerge in the 
event of financing shortfalls, and the combined effect of output contraction and lari depreciation 
would have repercussions on the banking sector, which is exposed to highly dollarized balance 
sheets of unhedged borrowers. For now, however, the Government of Georgia expects the 
foreign exchange market to remain relatively stable through the remainder of 2009, aided by 
smoother exchange rate adjustment associated with the auction system. 
 
  3.  Monetary Policy 
 
11.  With limited scope for reviving credit growth through interest rate cuts and liquidity 
injections, Georgia's short-term monetary strategy is to ease credit conditions through selective 
instruments such as foreign exchange swaps, in an effort to encourage domestic currency 
lending.  Meanwhile,  liquidity  injections  from  external  budgetary  support  will  be  allowed  to 
increase reserve money sufficiently to meet banks’ demand for higher precautionary balances. 
 
  4.  Fiscal Policy 
 
12.  Georgia's fiscal deficit is projected to increase from the original projection of 5.6% of 
GDP to 9.4% in 2009, due mainly to the downward revision in GDP growth. Fiscal deficits in the 
second half of 2009 and in 2010 will be financed by a mix of T-bill issuance, privatization 
receipts, and external budget support. Part of the balance of payments support provided by the 
IMF in 2009 ($100 million) will be channeled to the budget. In 2010, all of the IMF financing is 
provisionally channeled to the budget pending confirmation of the amount of budget support that 
is in the pipeline from other international financial institutions. Beyond 2010, the adjustment 
strategy will continue to rely on containing expenditure and broadening the tax base while 
further reducing income tax rates once conditions permit.

Appendix 4 23
      
GUARANTOR: SOCIÉTÉ GÉNÉRALE 
 
A.  Business Overview and Strategy 
 
1.  Overview. The Société Générale Group,1 one of the leading universal banks in Europe, 
has the seventh-largest market capitalization in the euro zone and a broad global presence, with 
163,000 employees in 82 countries, serving 30 million individual customers worldwide. 
 
2.  Business operations. Société Générale is focused on four key business areas: (i) retail 
banking; (ii) financial services (consumer credit, equipment finance, vehicle finance, information 
technology  leasing,  insurance);  (iii)  global  investment  management  and  services  (asset 
management,  private  banking,  securities  services,  online  banking);  and  (iv)  corporate  and 
investment banking, in which Société Générale ranks among the leading banks worldwide in 
euro capital markets, derivatives, and structured finance.  
 
3.  Business strategy. The group has three strategic priorities: (i) maintaining a balanced 
business mix, (ii) achieving long-term growth, and (iii) increasing operating efficiency. To carry 
out these priorities, the group’s strategy for 2008–2010 includes increasing development in 
high-potential businesses and markets (international expansion of retail banking and consumer 
credit, and private banking), to be funded through high capital generation from its French 
networks  and  its  corporate  and  investment  banking  business.  The  group’s  international 
expansion in the long term will focus on retail banking in the Russian Federation, Central and 
Eastern Europe, and the Mediterranean Basin, and on consumer banking activity in the BRIC 
(Brazil, Russian Federation, India, People’s Republic of China) countries and other emerging 
markets. The strategy also includes enhancing revenue synergies between businesses, and 
reinforcing security and operational efficiency to ensure robust, profitable, and balanced growth.  
 
8.  Business  performance.  The  year  2007  was  a  difficult  one  for  financial  markets 
worldwide; the subprime crisis and follow-on liquidity crisis had far-reaching effects. The group 
was not immune to these problems; in the second half of 2007, Société Générale’s corporate 
and investment banking was affected by fallout from the United States financial crisis, and its 
asset management group was affected by the liquidity crisis. Moreover, the group suffered from 
fraud committed by a rogue trader in its capital market activities, resulting in an exceptional loss 
of €4.9 billion. These difficulties affected both revenue, which was down 2.8% from 2006,2 and 
net income, which was down 81.9% from 2006. Despite these challenges, the group had a 
profitable year in 2007, earning net income of €947 million. This strong performance was driven 
by its diverse range of activities, the positive performance of its retail banking networks, and the 
strong growth of its financial services, private banking, and securities services activities. The 
after-tax return on equity was 3.6% (17.1% excluding the effects of the fraud).  
 
9.  Despite the deepening of the global economic crisis in 2008, the group reported net 
income  of  €2,773  million  as  of  year-end  2008.  Earnings  were  supported  by  the  group's 
performance in the retail banking business, both in France and internationally, as well as its 
financial services, custody, futures brokerage, and online banking business lines. As of 30 June 
2009, the group's net income rebounded to positive levels following negative earnings in the first 
quarter of 2009, related to credit costs and securities write-downs. Société Générale posted net 
                                                 
1  Société Générale. 2008. Presentation to Debt Investors. June. Available: http://library.corporate-ir.net; Société 
Générale. 2008. Société Générale Group Strategic Outlook. March. Available: http://media.corporate-ir.net; Société 
Générale. 2008. Press Release Activities and Results in 2007. 21 February. Available: http://media.corporate-ir.net 
2  When adjusted for changes in the group’s structure and at constant exchange rates.

24  Appendix 4 
income of €244 million as of mid-2009, comparing favorably to the €278 million loss in the prior 
quarter. Contributing to the return to profitability were particularly strong revenues in corporate 
and investment banking and steady performance in retail banking. 
 
10.  Response to the fraud. After the discovery of the rogue trading in 2007, immediate 
measures  were  taken  and  structural  plans  put  in  place  to  tighten  Société  Générale’s  risk 
management  and  internal  control  policies  and  procedures.  These  included  enhancing 
operational  controls  such  as  (i)  stricter  controls  over  operations  and  reporting  of  nominal 
positions, (ii) improved transaction confirmation procedures, (iii) strengthened management alert 
processes,  and  (iv)  stricter  compliance  with  mandatory  holiday  procedures.  Information 
technology security was also tightened, as were controls over access to information systems, 
and limits applicable to stress tests and arbitrage volume were temporarily decreased. Plans 
were also put in place to tighten controls across the organization by (i) reengineering the control 
function’s  organization  and  procedures;  and  (ii) creating  a  department  responsible  for  the 
security of operations, independent from front and back channels, and including a special team 
responsible for uncovering fraudulent behavior.  
 
11.  Credit ratings. The group is currently rated Aa2 by Moody’s, A+ by Standard & Poor’s, 
and A+ by Fitch Ratings. 
 
C.  Société Générale Guarantee 
 
12.  Société Générale will give a guarantee in favor of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in 
respect of any default in payment other than a default due to certain excepted country risk 
events; ADB will therefore be exposed to the excepted risks.
